properties.author: Stephan Bauer (first version: Stephan Bauer, Gi-Won Chung, Michael Kraxner, Sara Pourmanouchehri)
properties.name: Archiving Digital Photographs 2
properties.description: This plan is part of the analysis how raw photos can be preserved. This analysis based on an inital analysis created for the UE Digital Preservation at TU Wien.

basis.designatedCommunity: The designated community is the photographer him/herself in the first place. We do focus on the so-called prosumer (professional consumer), who manly takes photos for private purposes and to a smaller degree for friends/family/other people.
basis.planningPurpose: The aim of this plan is to find a strategy how to deal with different raw files in order to find a solution how to preserve these proprietary files in a homogenous and sustainable way. As the company specific raw files are generally spoken not well suited for long time preservation we have to find a more open and well documented format that allows to store the image data as well as the metadata. Due to a huge amount of different conversion tools it is also crucial to find efficient and reliable ones. As the existing collection of photos is far too large to perform conversion manually, the tool should allow to batch converts images.
basis.preservationRights: The photographer has all rights to change, modify and convert his/her images.

trigger.description: Although some minor steps were performed to convert raw images, there is yet no preservation plan in use.

sampleRecords.samplesDescription: The sample records represent typical photos in a collection of a prosumer. There are quite old raw files, as well as new ones, there are raws from compact camera as well as from DSLRs and from different vendors. As these raw files greatly differ it is important to verify if the tools and formats can handle this inhomogeneity.

collectionProfile.description: Collection of different raw files as generated by digital still image cameras.
collectionProfile.retentionPeriod: The oldest raw formats are approximately 7 or 8 years old. As the images do have a certain personal value, they should be preserved for approximately 80 years.

record.description: CRW from a CANON Powershot S45 at ISO 100. The image is showing a ColorCheckerBoard and uses a custom white balance. The associated THM file ist not uploaded.
CR2 from a CANON EOS 5D Mk2 at ISO 1600. The raw has a reduced size (so called sRAW2) which is roughly a quarter of the full resolution.

CR2 from a CANON EOS 40D at ISO 400. The image contains GPS metadata that has been added at capture time using a Canon W-Lan Module and a Garmin 60Cx. The current position can be read from the display of the photographed GPS device.
NEF from a Nikon D80 at ISO 800.

alternative.name: Adobe DNG Converter -c
alternative.description: Convert image to DNG lossless compressed with default (medium) thumbnails using the Adobe DNG Converter 6.1

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: 1. Adobe DNG Converter 6.1: http://www.adobe.com/support/downloads/detail.jsp?ftpID=4724. 2. Raw files to convert.
resourceDescription.configSettings: Under Windows: the converter can be run by typing the path to the executable file followed by the parameters. Note: at least one parameter has to be given when running the CLI. Under Mac OS X: You need to type to entire path to executable file, which is inside the Application bundle.
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Adobe is the original promoter and inventor of the DNG format. The Adobe DNG Converter and the underlying SDK represent the de-facto reference implementation. Adobe DNG Converter offers a clear possibility for integration. Therefore the migration process can be fully automated. The compression is truly lossless. Therefore it should be safe to consider this option, since there should (theoretically) be no degradation in quality. This alternative can save some space, if it should become an issue in future.

experiment.description: Exporting using Adobe DNG Converter 6.1.0.250 on Mac OS 10.6.3. The OS is running on a Intel Core 2 Duo with 4 GB RAM. Results are retrieved manually.
experiment.settings: Compressions is enabeld by default. The preview size is medium per default. The original raw file is not embedded.

alternative.name: Adobe DNG Converter -u
alternative.description: Convert image to DNG uncompressed with default (medium) thumbnails using the Adobe DNG Converter 6.1

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: 1. Adobe DNG Converter 6.1: http://www.adobe.com/support/downloads/detail.jsp?ftpID=4724. 2. Raw files to convert.
resourceDescription.configSettings: Under Windows: the converter can be run by typing the path to the executable file followed by the parameters. Note: at least one parameter has to be given when running the CLI. => -u Under Mac OS X: You need to type to entire path to executable file, which is inside the Application bundle.
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Adobe is the original promoter and inventor of the DNG format. The Adobe DNG Converter and the underlying SDK represent the de-facto reference implementation. Adobe DNG Converter offers a clear possibility for integration. Therefore the migration process can be fully automated. Since the files are uncompressed it might be more future-proof. Some users report that there may be less vulnerability to noise in poor light. This option should get serious attention for pictures shot under extreme conditions or if more extensive postprocessing is in consideration.

experiment.description: Exporting using Adobe DNG Converter 6.1.0.250 on Mac OS 10.6.3. The OS is running on a Intel Core 2 Duo with 4 GB RAM. Results are retrieved manually.
experiment.settings: Compressions is disabeld by selecting the vustom DNG compatibility "DNG 1.3" and select "Nicht komprimiert". The preview size is medium per default. The original raw file is not embedded.

alternative.name: digiKam DNG Converter -c
alternative.description: Convert image to DNG lossless compressed with default (medium) thumbnails using digiKam 0.6.0-svn

resourceDescription.configSettings: Full automatic configuration not possible. The tool requires user interaction. Migration/Evaluation has to happen external. Converting using digiKam 0.6.0-svn (Build date: 2.11.2009) as Kipi-plugin in digiKam 0.10.0 on openSUSE 11.2, KDE 4.3.1 release 6.
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Regarding compression: Since the files are uncompressed it might be more future-proof. Some users report that there may be less vulnerability to noise in poor light. This option should get serious attention for pictures shot under extreme conditions or if more extensive postprocessing is in consideration. It should be noted that there might be not all the metadata saved.

experiment.description: Converting using DNG Image Converter 1.2.0 (Build date: 15.4.2010) as standalone application on Kubuntu 10.04, KDE 4.4.2. The OS is running inside a virtual box with 2860 MB RAM and 2 CPUs. Results are retrieved manually.
experiment.settings: Compression is enabled, the JPEG Preview size is set to Medium, the original raw file is not embedded.

alternative.name: digiKam DNG Converter -u
alternative.description: Convert image to DNG uncompressed with default (medium) thumbnails using digiKam 0.6.0-svn

resourceDescription.configSettings: Full automatic configuration not possible. The tool requires user interaction. Migration/Evaluation has to happen external. Converting using digiKam 0.6.0-svn (Build date: 2.11.2009) as Kipi-plugin in digiKam 0.10.0 on openSUSE 11.2, KDE 4.3.1 release 6.
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Files are uncompressed, which might be considered as more future-proof. Some users report that there may be less vulnerability to noise in poor light. This option should get serious attention for pictures shot under extreme conditions or if more extensive postprocessing is in consideration. It should be noted that there might be not all the metadata saved.

experiment.description: Converting using DNG Image Converter 1.2.0 (Build date: 15.4.2010) as standalone application on Kubuntu 10.04, KDE 4.4.2. The OS is running inside a virtual box with 2860 MB RAM and 2 CPUs. Results are retrieved manually.
experiment.settings: Compression is disabled, the JPEG Preview size is set to Medium, the original raw file is not embedded.

alternative.name: ACR TIFF 6.0 -c 16 AdobeRGB
alternative.description: Convert image to a ZIP compressed TIFF 6.0 using Adobe Camera RAW 5.7

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: 1. The Adobe Camera RAW Plugin: http://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop/cameraraw.html 2. A supported SW product by Adobe: Adobe Photoshop, Bridge or Lightroom 3. Raw files to convert.
resourceDescription.configSettings: Exporting using Adobe Camera RAW 5.7.0.213 on Mac OS 10.6.3 executed from Adobe Bridge CS4. All parameters are set to "Camera Raw-Standards".
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Adobe is one of the big players in delivering professional and high-quality photo software. The Adobe Camera Raw Plugin as used by Adobe Bridge, Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Lightroom represents a de-facto standard in RAW conversion. Exporting to a compressed TIFF results in an acceptable filesize, but may make the image more vulnerable to bit errors. Using 16 Bit guarantees that the image data is preserved in the best way possible. Using AdobeRGB represents a compromise between the narrow sRGB and the larger ProPhotoRGB.

experiment.description: Exporting using Adobe Camera RAW 5.7.0.213 on Mac OS 10.6.3 executed from Adobe Bridge CS4. The OS is running on a Intel Core 2 Duo with 4 GB RAM. Results are retrieved manually.
experiment.settings: All parameters are set to "Camera Raw-Standards". The export settings are ZIP compressed TIFF, 16 Bit, AdobeRGB, in original size.

alternative.name: ACR TIFF 6.0 -u 16 AdobeRGB
alternative.description: Convert image to an uncompressed TIFF 6.0 using Adobe Camera RAW 5.7

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: 1. The Adobe Camera RAW Plugin: http://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop/cameraraw.html 2. A supported SW product by Adobe: Adobe Photoshop, Bridge or Lightroom 3. Raw files to convert.
resourceDescription.configSettings: Exporting using Adobe Camera RAW 5.7.0.213 on Mac OS 10.6.3 executed from Adobe Bridge CS4. All parameters are set to "Camera Raw-Standards".
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Adobe is one of the big players in delivering professional and high-quality photo software. The Adobe Camera Raw Plugin as used by Adobe Bridge, Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Lightroom represents a de-facto standard in RAW conversion. Exporting to an uncompressed TIFF results in a very large file size, but may be preferable in contrast to compressed TIFF. Using 16 Bit guarantees that the image data is preserved in the best way possible. Using AdobeRGB represents a compromise between the narrow sRGB and the larger ProPhotoRGB.

experiment.description: Exporting using Adobe Camera RAW 5.7.0.213 on Mac OS 10.6.3 executed from Adobe Bridge CS4. The OS is running on a Intel Core 2 Duo with 4 GB RAM. Results are retrieved manually.
experiment.settings: All parameters are set to "Camera Raw-Standards". The export settings are uncompressed TIFF, 16 Bit, AdobeRGB, in original size.

resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: JPEG 2000 provides interesting features like lossless compression or 16 bit per channel. On the other hand the format is yet not wide spread in the photo community. There are only few tools that convert directly to JPEG 2000.

JPEG is one of the most widespread file formats for photos. It is supported by a wide range of products. On the other hand it typically involves lossy compression and normally does not support 16 Bit per channel.

alternative.name: Do Nothing
alternative.description: Keep the status quo and do not perform any migration steps

resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: This option is the one with the least effort and with the least short time risks. This alternative may be dangerous on a long time scale. All image data is preserved without any loss.

decision.reason: The suggested alternatives can be tested, as the necessary software is available. The discarded alternatives do not fulfill the high quality requirements on one hand (JPEG) and on the other hand there is too weak support by tools (JPEG 2000). It may be interesting to reevaluate the use of JPEG 2000 in one year.

recommendation.reasoning: DNG is the best suited format when considering migration. The Adobe DNG Converter is freely available and provides convenient results when migrating raw files. Users that do have enough storage space may also consider using uncompressed DNG files.
recommendation.effects: Images will be batched converted using Adobe DNG Converter 6.1. To ensure proper migration quality image content and context tests may be performed.
